metadata.case_name: Basti Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Twenty-one workmen

facts.text: Twenty-one persons (respondents) engaged from November 21, 1958, to February 5, 1959, in removal of press-mud in appellant's sugar factory.
Services of the twenty-one respondents terminated on February 6, 1959.

Respondents paid wages lower than Rs. 55/- per month (minimum wage under Standing Orders dated October 3, 1958 for vacuum pan sugar factories of Uttar Pradesh) for period November 21, 1958 to February 5, 1959.
Appellant contended work of removal of press-mud given to contractor Banarsi Das, who employed the 21 men; contractor left work on February 6, 1959, and terminated their services.
Respondents contended they were employed directly by management of the company.

Governor of Uttar Pradesh referred dispute to Labour Court, Lucknow on July 31, 1962: (1) Whether termination from February 6, 1959 legal/justifiable? If not, relief? (2) Whether payment below minimum wage legal/justified? If not, relief?

Labour Court accepted appellant's case that workmen employed by contractor Banarsi Das, but held appellant employer under s.2(i)(iv) UP Industrial Disputes Act, 1947; entitled to Standing Orders minimum wages and reinstatement.

Labour Court ordered: (a) payment at Rs.55/- per month from Feb 6, 1959 to end of 1958-59 crushing season; (b) reinstatement if not already employed in 1962-63 season; (c) difference of wages for Nov 21, 1958 to Feb 5, 1959 (Rs.55/month and specific daily rates).
No materials on record showing how many workmen employed in 1962-63 crushing season had worked in latter half of 1961-62 season under cl. K of Standing Orders.

legal_issues.text: Whether employers terminated services of workmen from February 6, 1959 legally and/or justifiably? If not, relief?
Whether action of employers in paying rates lower than minimum wage of Rs.55 per month for November 21, 1958 to February 5, 1959 legal/justified? If not, relief?
Whether definition of 'employer' in sub-cl.(iv) of s.2(i) of UP Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 makes appellant the employer of contractor's workmen?
Whether the definition violates Art.19(1)(g) of Constitution?
Whether respondents entitled to benefit of Standing Orders minimum wage as 'workmen employed by a factory'?

petitioner_arguments.text: 21 workmen not employed by management; work given to contractor Banarsi Das who employed them and terminated services.
Definition of employer in sub-cl.(iv) s.2(i) does not make owner employer of contractor's laborers; makes owner employer of contractor.
If definition makes contractor's laborers workmen of company, it violates Art.19(1)(g).
Respondents not 'workmen' under Standing Orders definition 'employed by a factory' which means employed by management, not contractor.
Reinstatement difficult due to cl. K of Standing Orders prioritizing seasonal workmen who worked second half of preceding season.

respondent_arguments.text: Employed directly by management of the company.

court_reasoning.text: Labour Court correctly held work done through contractor Banarsi Das; appellant is employer under sub-cl.(iv) s.2(i) where owner contracts for execution of work ordinarily part of industry.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Definition makes owner employer of workmen engaged through contractor to prevent evasion of Act.

court_reasoning.text: Definition of 'workmen' in s.2(z) wide enough to include contractor labor; extended employer definition ensures industrial dispute coverage.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Respondents are workmen of appellant under s.2(z) read with s.2(i)(iv).

court_reasoning.text: Even if restriction on trade, in interests of general public to prevent evasion via contractors; does not violate Art.19(1)(g).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions of Industrial Disputes Act in public interest.

court_reasoning.text: 'Employed by a factory' in Standing Orders includes workmen employed by contractors; wide enough, no reason to exclude.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Purpose to apply terms to all workmen under Act definitions.

court_reasoning.text: No materials to consider cl. K difficulties for reinstatement; if facts known, would limit reinstatement without breaching cl. K as in Mahalakshmi case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No evidence on prior season work of current employees.

holdings.text: Appellant is employer of respondents under s.2(i)(iv) UP Industrial Disputes Act; respondents entitled to Standing Orders benefits including minimum wages.
'Employed by a factory' includes contractor's workmen.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mahalakshmi Sugar Mills Company Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar circumstances for limiting reinstatement to avoid breach of standing orders cl. K.

statutes_cited.name: Uttar Pradesh Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Definitions of employer and workmen include contractor labor; basis for standing orders application.

statutes_cited.name: Standing Orders for Vacuum Pan Sugar Factories of Uttar Pradesh
statutes_cited.relevance: Minimum wage Rs.55/month; definition of workmen; seasonal employment priority.

outcome.summary: Appeal against Labour Court award dismissed; upheld appellant as employer, entitlement to minimum wages and reinstatement (subject to cl. K if facts proven, but no materials).
outcome.relief_granted: Labour Court orders stand: back wages from Feb 6, 1959 to end 1958-59 season; reinstatement if possible; wage differences for prior period.

key_quotes.text: The obvious purpose of this extended definition of the word employer is to make the owner of the industry..., in the circumstances mentioned..., the employer of the workmen engaged in the work which is done through contract.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains intent of s.2(i)(iv) to cover contractor labor.

key_quotes.text: The interests of the general public require that the device of the engagement of a contractor... should not be allowed to be availed of by owners of industry for evading the provisions of the Industrial Disputes Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: On the ordinary grammatical sense of the words 'employed by a factory' they include... every person who is employed to do the work of the factory.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets Standing Orders to include contractor workmen.
